AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Animal/Monster Handler: responsible for the safe keeping, dietary care, and exercise of animals or monsters.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Arborist: maintains and cares for trees, often by surgically removing dying limbs.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Baler: bales hay, or in the mills, wool and cotton goods.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Beekeeper: owns and breeds bees, especially for their honey.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Dairyboy/Dairymaid: milks cows and makes cheese and butter.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Falconer: keeps, trains, and hunts with falcons, hawks, or other birds of prey.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Farmer: operates a farm or cultivates land.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Florist: grows and arranges plants and cut flowers.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Forager: searches for food in the wild.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Forester: supervises the wellbeing of a forest.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Gamekeeper: breeds and protects game, typically for a large estate.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Groom: cleans and brushes the coats of horses, dogs, or other animals.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Herder: supervises a herd of livestock or makes a living from keeping livestock, especially in open country.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Horse Trainer: tends to horses and teaches them different disciplines.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Hunter: hunts game or other wild animals.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Lumberjack: fells trees, cuts them into logs, and transports them to a sawmill.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Master-of-Horses: supervises and commands all horses under a jurisdiction.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Master-of-Hounds: maintains a pack of hounds and their associated staff, equipment, and hunting arrangements.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Miller: owns or works in a grain mill.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Miner: works underground in mines in order to obtain minerals such as coal, diamonds, or gold.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Pathfinder: scouts ahead and discovers a path or way for others.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Prospector: searches for mineral deposits, especially by drilling and excavation.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Ranger: wanders or ranges over a particular area or domain.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Renderer: converts waste animal tissue into usable materials.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Thresher: separates grain from the plants by beating.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Trapper: traps wild animals, especially for their fur.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Vintner: engages in winemaking, especially with monitoring and harvesting the grapes.
AGRICULTURE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY, & FORESTR.Zookeeper: maintains and cares for animals or monsters in a zoo.

ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Architect: designs buildings or landscapes and in many cases supervises their construction.
ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Brickmaker: crafts bricks from clay, stone, or other materials.
ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Brickmason / Bricklayer / Mason: builds with mineral products such as stones, bricks, cinder blocks, or tiles, usually with the use of mortar as a bonding agent.
ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Carpenter: makes and repairs wooden objects and structures.
ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Construction Worker: a laborer in the physical construction of a built environment and its infrastructure.
ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Glazier: fits glass into windows and doors.
ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Plasterer: applies plaster to walls, ceilings, or other surfaces.
ARCHITECTURE & CONSTRUCTION.Stonemason: cuts and prepares stone for use in construction.

ARTS / Artists / artistic.Actor: impersonates characters, typically on stage in a theatrical production.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Arranger: adapts a musical composition for performance.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Busker/Street Musician: performs in a public place, often for money.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Chef: a professional cook trained in the culinary arts.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Curator: keeper and custodian of a museum or other collections of precious items.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Dancer: moves their body rhythmically with or without musical accompaniment.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Glasspainter: produces colorful designs on or in glass.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Jester: professional joker or 'fool' at court, typically wearing a cap with bells on it and carrying a mock scepter.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Minstrel: recites lyric or heroic poetry for nobility.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Poet: writes ballads, epics, sonnets, or other forms of poetry.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Sculptor: crafts art by carving or casting blocks of marble, stones, or other hardened minerals.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Singer/Soprano: sings with or without instrumental accompaniment.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Skald: composes and recites poems honoring heroes and their deeds.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Stage Magician: deceives their audience with seemingly impossible feats while using only natural means.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Tattooist: illustrates the skin with indelible patterns, pictures, legends, etc.
ARTS / Artists / artistic.Writer: commits his or her thoughts, ideas, etc., into written language.

BUSINESS & TRADE.Animal Collector/Monster Collector: collects and deals in rare and exotic animals and monsters.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Business Owner: owns a business entity in an attempt to profit from its successful operations.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Debt Collector: recovers money owed on delinquent accounts.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Appraiser: assesses the monetary value of something.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Auctioneer: conducts auctions by accepting bids and declaring goods sold.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Bagniokeeper: owner of a bath house or brothel.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Collector: collects things of a specified type, professionally or as a hobby.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Guild Master: leads an economically independent producer (a 'guild,' an association of craftsmen or merchants that often holds considerable bureaucratic power).
BUSINESS & TRADE.Land Surveyor: establishes maps and boundaries for ownership or other purposes required by government or civil law.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Moneylender: lends money to others who pay interest.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Peddler: travels from place to place selling assorted items.
BUSINESS & TRADE.Plantation Owner: an owner of an estate on which crops are cultivated by resident labor, typically slave labor.

COMMUNICATIONS.Herald: a messenger who carries important news.
COMMUNICATIONS.Interpreter: interprets language and its meaning, especially within ancient manuscripts.
COMMUNICATIONS.Town Crier: makes public announcements in the streets or marketplace.

CRAFTSMANSHIP.Armorer: specializes in making and repairing armor.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Blacksmith: forges and repairs things in metal, including weapons, armor, utensils, etc.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Bladesmith: specializes in making and repairing bladed weapons, especially swords and daggers.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Candlemaker: makes candles and wax from honey and tallow.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Cartwright: makes and repairs carts and wagons.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Cooper/Hooper: makes and repairs casks and barrels.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Engraver: incises a design onto a hard surface by cutting grooves into it.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Goldsmith/Silversmith: a smith who specializes in precious metals.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Lapidary: turns stone, minerals, or gemstones into decorative items such as cabochons, engraved gems, and faceted designs.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Leatherworker: makes items from leather such as pouches, scabbards, straps, etc.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Jeweler: designs, makes, and repairs necklaces, bracelets, watches, etc., often containing jewels.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Mercer: weaves textile fabrics, especially silks, velvets, and other fine materials.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Potter: makes pots, bowls, plates, etc., out of clay.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Restorer: repairs or renovates a work of art so as to return it to its original condition.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Rugmaker: makes and repairs rugs by braiding, hooking, weaving, etc.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Seamstress/Tailor: makes, alters, repairs, as well as occasionally designing garments.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Soaper: makes soap from accumulated mutton fat, wood ash, and natural soda.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Tanner: treats the skins and hides of animals to produce leather.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Taxidermist: prepares, stuffs, and mounts the skins of animals.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Tinker: travels from place to place mending utensils.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Watchmaker: makes and repairs watches and clocks.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Weaponsmith: specializes in making and repairing weapons.
CRAFTSMANSHIP.Weaver: makes fabric by weaving fiber together.

CRIME.Assassin: murders through stealth for reasons pertaining to money, politics, or religion.
CRIME.Bandit: a robber or outlaw belonging to a gang and typically operating in an isolated or lawless area.
CRIME.Burglar: illegally enters buildings and steals things.
CRIME.Charlatan/Conman: tricks people by gaining their trust and persuading them to believe something that is not true in order to benefit from the encounter.
CRIME.Cockfighter/Gamefighter: engages in arena matches in which animals or monsters are pitted against one another, typically to the death.
CRIME.Crime Boss: controls and supervises a criminal organization.
CRIME.Extortioner: extorts money from someone by threatening to expose embarrassing information about them.
CRIME.Kidnapper: abducts people and holds them captive, typically to obtain a ransom.
CRIME.Loan Shark: charges extremely high rates of interest for moneylending, typically under illegal conditions.
CRIME.Pirate: attacks and robs ships at sea.
CRIME.Poisoner: makes poisons to harm or kill.
CRIME.Raider/Marauder: makes sudden, unprompted attacks against defenseless or near-defenseless settlements.
CRIME.Smuggler: manages the import or export of goods secretly, in violation of the law, especially without payment of legal duty.
CRIME.Thief: steals peopleâ€™s property, especially by stealth and without using force or violence.

GOVERNMENT & LAW.Agister: affords pasture to the livestock of others for a price.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Courtier: attends court as a companion or adviser to the king or queen.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Knight: serves his or her sovereign after being bestowed a rank of royal honor.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Lady-in-Waiting: attends a queen, princess, or other high-ranking feminine nobleperson.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Master-of-Coin: supervises the royal treasury, advises the monarch on financial matters, and is responsible for raising money through taxation.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Notary: performs certain legal formalities, especially to draw up or certify contracts, deeds, and other documents for use in other jurisdictions.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Orator/Spokesman: makes statements on behalf of a group or individual nobleperson.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Squire: an attendant to a knight, typically in training for knighthood.
GOVERNMENT & LAW.Warden: a person responsible for the supervision of a place or person.

HEALTH.Apothecary: a person who prepares and sells medicines.
HEALTH.Veterinarian: a doctor who specializes in animals.

MERCHANTS.Baker: bakes bread and pastries for sale.
MERCHANTS.Merchant: a person who sells goods and services.
MERCHANTS.Peddler: travels selling goods from place to place.
MERCHANTS.Silk Merchant: trades in silk and silk goods.

NOBILITY.Baron: a member of the lowest order of the British nobility.
NOBILITY.Count/Earl: a nobleman ranking above a viscount and below a marquess.
NOBILITY.Duke/Duchess: rules over a duchy and is of the highest rank below the monarch.
NOBILITY.King/Queen: the ruler of an independent state and its people.
NOBILITY.Lord/Lady: a nobleperson with authority, often governing land or people.
NOBILITY.Prince/Princess: the direct descendant of a monarch.

SERVANTS.Chamberlain: a high-ranking servant in a royal household.
SERVANTS.Valet: attends to a gentleman's personal needs.

RELIGION.Priest: a person authorized to perform religious rituals.

SCHOOLS.Alchemist: practices alchemy, transforming base metals into gold or finding the elixir of life.
SCHOOLS.Astrologer: studies celestial bodies and their influence on human affairs.
SCHOOLS.Philosopher: seeks knowledge and wisdom through inquiry and reasoning.
SCHOOLS.Wordsmith: draws their power from language and casts by dictation.

MILITARY & SECURITY.Admiral: commands a fleet or naval squadron.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Bodyguard: escorts and protects another person, especially a dignitary.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Bouncer: prevents troublemakers from entering or ejects them from the premises of an establishment.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Captain: an army officer of high rank in charge of commanding squadrons of soldiers.
MILITARY & SECURITY.City Watch: an officer of law enforcement who resides in larger towns or cities.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Commissar: teaches principles and policies to military units.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Constable: an officer with limited policing authority, typically in a small town.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Drummer/Fifer: a non-combatant foot soldier who sounds signals for changes in formation in combat.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Executioner: carries out a sentence of death on a legally condemned person.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Guard/Sentinel: a person who keeps watch, especially a soldier or other person formally assigned to protect a person or to control access to a place.
MILITARY & SECURITY.General: the chief commander of an army.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Inspection Officer: responsible for the inspection of military units to ensure they meet appropriate standards of training and efficiency.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Intelligence Officer: collects, compiles, and organizes information about the enemy.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Jailer: supervises a jail and the prisoners in it.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Lieutenant: an officer of middle rank in the armed forces.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Marksman/Archer: uses long-range weapons, such as the bow, crossbow, sling, etc. to inflict damage from afar.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Marshall: has charge of the cavalry in the household of a monarch.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Medic: a medical practitioner equipped for the battlefield.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Mercenary: a soldier without allegiance who works for money, typically a member of a company or guild.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Privateer: engages in maritime warfare under a commission of war.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Quartermaster: responsible for providing quarters, rations, clothing, and other supplies.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Royal Guard: responsible for the protection of a royal person.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Runner: carries information between lines in wartime.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Sapper: a soldier responsible for tasks such as building and repairing roads and bridges, laying and clearing mines, etc.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Sergeant: an officer instructed with a protective duty, typically worth 'half a knight' in regard.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Sergeant-at-Arms: charged with keeping order during meetings and, if necessary, participates in battle.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Scout: sent ahead of a main force to gather information about the enemyâ€™s position, strength, or movements.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Siege Artillerist: works the artillery machines of an army.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Slave Driver: oversees and urges on slaves at work.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Spy: secretly collects and reports information on the activities, movements, and plans of an enemy or competitor.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Tactician: uses a carefully planned military strategy to achieve a specific end.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Tollkeeper: collects tolls at a bridge, road etc. where a charge is made.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Torturer: inflicts severe pain on someone as punishment or to force them to do or say something.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Warden: responsible for the supervision of a particular place or thing or for ensuring that regulations associated with it are obeyed.
MILITARY & SECURITY.Warmage: a soldier skilled in destructive battle magic.

RELIGION / CHURCH.Abbot/Abbess: the head of an abbey of monks.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Acolyte: assists the celebrant in a religious service or procession.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Almoner: distributes money and food to poor people.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Archbishop: responsible for an archdiocese and its surrounding district.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Bishop: a senior member of the clergy, usually in charge of a diocese and empowered to confer holy orders.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Cantor: sings liturgical music and leads prayer in a synagogue.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Cardinal: a leading dignitary of a church, nominated by the highest official.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Chaplain: a member of the clergy attached to a private chapel, institution, ship, or branch of the armed forces.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Cleric: has devoted their entire being to the will of their god, thus gaining magical powers.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Confessor: hears confessions and gives absolution and spiritual counsel.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Cultist: a member of a cult who generally lives outside of conventional society and worships an unorthodox patron.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Cult Leader: the organizational leader of a cult who is occasionally also the founder.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Deacon: an ordained minister of an order ranking below that of priest.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Diviner: seeks ultimate divination in order to further understand or meet godly substance.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Exorcist: expels or attempts to expel evil spirits from a person or place.
RELIGION / CHURCH.High Priest/Pope: the chief priest of a religion.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Inquisitor: seeks to eliminate heresy and other things contrary to the doctrine or teachings of their faith.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Missionary: goes on a religious mission to promote their faith in a foreign place.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Monk: able to manifest their spirituality through a calm, centered being and thus gain abilities that function similarly to magic.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Nun: a member of a religious community of women, especially a cloistered one, living under vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Paladin: a holy knight and divine spellcaster crusading in the name of good and order.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Pardoner: raises money for religious works by soliciting offerings and granting indulgences.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Priest: has the authority to perform certain rites and administer certain sacraments.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Prophet: regarded as an inspired teacher or proclaimer of the will of God.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Sexton: looks after a church and churchyard, sometimes acting as bell-ringer and formerly as a gravedigger.
RELIGION / CHURCH.Templar: fights in a religious military order.

SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Anthropologist: studies the customs, beliefs, and relationships of humanoids and intellectually and culturally advanced creatures.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Apprentice: studies a trade under a skilled employer.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Archaeologist: studies humanoid history and prehistory through the excavation of sites and the analysis of artifacts and other physical remains.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Archivist: maintains and is in charge of archives.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Assayer: determiner of the proportions of metal in ore and the amount of copper, silver, gold, or platinum in coins.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Astronomer: makes observations of celestial and scientific phenomena within the material plane.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Botanist: an expert in or student of the scientific study of plants.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Cartographer: a scholar and illustrator of maps.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Chemist: engaged in chemical research or experiments.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Drakologist: studies or is an expert in the branch of zoology concerned with dragons.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Herbalist: practices healing by the use of herbs.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Historian: an expert in or student of history, especially that of a particular period, geographical region, or social phenomenon.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Librarian: administers or assists in a library.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Mathematician: a scholar of the abstract science of number, quantity, and space.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Mortician: prepares dead bodies for burial or cremation and makes arrangements for funerals.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Nurse: cares for the sick or infirm, especially in a hospital.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Philosopher: a scholar of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Professor: a teacher of the highest rank in a college or university.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Student: attends school or learns under others to enter and pursue a particular subject.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Teacher: instructs on a particular skill or subject.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Theologian: engages in the study of the nature of God and religious belief.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Tutor: charged with the instruction and guidance of another.
SCIENCE, MATH, & EDUCATION.Zoologist: an expert in or a student of the behavior, physiology, classification, and distribution of animals.

TRANSPORTATION.Bosun: in charge of organizing the equipment and crew of a ship.
TRANSPORTATION.Caravaneer: travels or lives in a caravan.
TRANSPORTATION.First Mate: the deck officer second in command to the master of a ship.
TRANSPORTATION.Navigator: directs the route or course of a ship or other form of transportation, especially by using instruments and maps.
TRANSPORTATION.Purser: keeps the accounts of a ship, especially as the head steward on a passenger vessel.
TRANSPORTATION.Sailor: works as a member of the crew of a commercial or naval ship or boat.
TRANSPORTATION.Shipwright: a carpenter skilled in ship construction and repair.

UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Adventurer: wanders the world in search of knowledge, treasure, fame, glory or a multitude of additional wants and desires.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Beggar/Pauper: lives by asking for money or food.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Blood Hunter/Monster Hunter: takes on jobs to hunt down and kill or capture dangerous creatures.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Bounty Hunter: pursues a criminal or fugitive for whom a reward is offered.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Deserter: a member of the armed forces who has deserted.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Disgraced Noble: a person of high birth who has since lost their respect, honor, or esteem in some or all noble circles.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Drunkard: a person who is habitually drunk and considers themselves a professional in the task.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Dungeon Delver: navigates underground labyrinths in search of any treasure they may find.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Exile: lives away from their native country, either from choice or compulsion.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Explorer: explores unfamiliar areas in search of geographical or scientific information.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Ex-Criminal: a person who has been convicted of a crime and has since served their sentence, or who has preemptively given up their life of crime.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Folk Hero: a celebrity who is greatly admired by many people of a particular kind or in a particular place.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Gambler: bets money on sports, card games, or games of chance in the hope of a profit.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Grave Robber/Tomb Raider: steals valuables from graves and tombs.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Hermit: lives in solitude, typically as a religious or spiritual discipline.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Housewife/Househusband: cares for their family by managing household affairs and completing housework.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Pilgrim: journeys to some sacred place as an act of religious devotion, occasionally to settle there.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Rag-and-Bone Man: collects unwanted household items and sells them to merchants.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Rebel/Political Dissident: rises in opposition or armed resistance against an established government or ruler.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Refugee: leaves their home in order to escape war, persecution, or natural disaster.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Scavenger/Mudlark/Tosher: searches for and collects discarded items.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Squatter: unlawfully occupies an uninhabited building or unused land.
UNEMPLOYED, SELF-EMPLOYED, & OUTCAST.Traveler/Wanderer/Vagabond: wanders from place to place without a permanent home or job.
